# Cambridge IGCSE™

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 347, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 293]]<|/det|>
0606/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 302, 150, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 302, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 855, 603]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a scientific calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- For \(\pi\) , use either your calculator value or 3.142.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 647]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 681]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 73, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 106, 782, 125]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 155, 675, 174]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 203, 683, 222]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 247, 680, 275]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 295, 683, 323]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 348, 656, 365]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 367, 560, 402]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 446, 225, 463]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 437, 905, 479]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 483, 770, 523]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 553, 217, 570]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 553, 667, 595]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 630, 217, 647]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 630, 570, 710]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 740, 160, 756]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 738, 555, 789]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A = 1 \\ \sec^2 A = 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A = 1 + \cot^2 A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 828, 240, 845]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 823, 576, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 616, 91]]<|/det|>
2 In this question, all lengths are in metres and time is in seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line such that its displacement \(s\) from a fixed point \(O\) at time \(t\) is given by \(s=(t-4)^{2}(t-1)\) for \(t \geqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 152, 144, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 151, 858, 168]]<|/det|>
(a) On the axes, sketch the displacement–time graph of \(P\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 181, 902, 523]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 540, 144, 556]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 540, 494, 556]]<|/det|>
(b) Find an expression for the velocity, \(v\), of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 556, 460, 571]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in a factorised form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 818, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) On the axes, sketch the velocity–time graph of \(P\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 103, 907, 428]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 443, 144, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 443, 529, 460]]<|/det|>
(d) Find an expression for the acceleration, \(a\), of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 552, 144, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 551, 850, 568]]<|/det|>
(e) On the axes, sketch the acceleration–time graph of \(P\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 364, 91]]<|/det|>
3 Functions f and g are such that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 103, 551, 133]]<|/det|>
\[
\mathrm{f}(x)=\frac{3 x}{x+4} \quad \text { for } x>0
\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 140, 570, 160]]<|/det|>
\[
\mathrm{g}(x)=\sqrt{x+2} \quad \text { for } x>-2
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 175, 359, 193]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\mathrm{fg}(x)=1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 84, 99, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 84, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 680, 103]]<|/det|>
4 (a) Given that \(y=4 \sin 2 x \cos 2 x\), find the value of \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\) when \(x=\frac{\pi}{6}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 84, 920, 101]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 408, 144, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 408, 485, 425]]<|/det|>
(b) A curve has equation \(y=4 \sin 2 x \cos 2 x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 435, 787, 462]]<|/det|>
The normal to the curve at the point where \(x=\frac{\pi}{6}\) meets the \(x\)-axis at the point \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 470, 406, 487]]<|/det|>
Find the exact coordinates of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 749, 91]]<|/det|>
5 (a) A 4-digit number is to be formed using the digits 0, 2, 4, 5, 6 and 8.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 88, 482, 104]]<|/det|>
The 4-digit number must not start with 0.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 104, 611, 121]]<|/det|>
Any digit may be used at most once in the 4-digit number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 136, 185, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 135, 570, 152]]<|/det|>
(i) Find how many 4-digit numbers can be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 214, 188, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 212, 611, 230]]<|/det|>
(ii) Find how many even 4-digit numbers can be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 352, 191, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 351, 740, 369]]<|/det|>
(iii) Find how many 4-digit numbers that are divisible by 5 can be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 536, 144, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 535, 618, 555]]<|/det|>
(b) Solve the equation \((n+1) \times{ }^{n+1} \mathrm{C}_{12}=33(n-10) \times{ }^{n} \mathrm{C}_{10}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 78, 99, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 700, 95]]<|/det|>
6 The volume, \(V\), of a sphere is increasing at the constant rate of \(2 \pi \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 91, 918, 110]]<|/det|>
Find the rate of change of the surface area, \(S\), of this sphere when the volume of the sphere is \(36 \pi \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 638, 91]]<|/det|>
7 The first three terms of an arithmetic progression can be written as

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 100, 465, 122]]<|/det|>
\[
2 \ln \left(x^{3}\right), \quad 5 \ln \left(x^{2}\right), \quad 2 \ln \left(x^{7}\right)
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 136, 144, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 135, 918, 172]]<|/det|>
(a) Given that \(x>1\), find the least number of terms for the sum of this progression to be greater than \(43 \ln \left(x^{24}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 816, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that the 25th term of this progression is equal to 408 , find the exact value of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
8

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 92, 900, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 421, 524, 454]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y=\frac{15}{x}-\frac{5}{x^{2}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 459, 443, 475]]<|/det|>
The curve meets the \(x\)-axis at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 473, 441, 490]]<|/det|>
The curve has a maximum at the point \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 520, 686, 537]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region enclosed by the line \(A B\) and the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 551, 372, 567]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in exact form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 465, 90]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 8.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 78, 144, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 682, 95]]<|/det|>
9 (a) Solve the equation \(3 \sec 3 x=\sqrt{3} \csc 3 x\) for \(-120^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 120^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 84, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 744, 102]]<|/det|>
(b) Solve the equation \(2 \cos \left(y+\frac{\pi}{3}\right) \sin \left(y+\frac{\pi}{3}\right)=\sin \left(y+\frac{\pi}{3}\right)\) for \(0 \leqslant y<2 \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 84, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 839, 665, 857]]<|/det|>
Question 10 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 88, 116, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 78, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
10 The first three terms, in descending powers of \(x\), in the expansion of \(\left(3 x^{2}-a\right)^{n}\left(1+\frac{1}{x^{2}}\right)^{2}\) can be written as \(729 x^{12}+972 x^{10}+b x^{8}\), where \(a, b\) and \(n\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 138, 348, 154]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a, b\) and \(n\).
